data.title: Lauren Laverne's Compilations of 2015
data.meta_description: Lauren Laverne picks her top compilations of 2015
data.text:
Every week on the show we play out some tracks from a compilation we are digging that week – sometimes it’s a new record or sometimes it’s revisiting a stellar golden oldie.

Here’s all the awesome compilations we selected in 2015:

Tropical Punch – Spunk Records 2014

A magnificient compilation from the Australian label Spunk Records, featuring big tracks from Tiny Ruins, Sun Kil Moon, Mogwai and Spoon to name but a few.

New Orleans Funk: The Original Sound of Funk 1960-1975

A classic Soul Jazz Records compilation that turns 15 this year but never gets old – we love it!

The Long Long Summer

A fantastic collection of electric tracks released on the French label La Dame Noir Records.

Next Stop Soweto: Zulu Rock, Afro Disco and Mbaqanga (u̇m-ba-ˈkän-ga) 1975-1985

This features some incredibly groovy music written during the apartheid in South Africa, it’s a beautiful record that proves that people can be creative and have a good time even in the most difficult times.

Tam...Tam...Tam...

This one was recorded back in 1958. All the music was written by Brazilian composer Jose Prates and performed by cast members of a touring show called ‘Brasiliana’. The album is now being re-issued by Trunk Records following a request by our very own Gilles Peterson.

Tropical Disco Hustle

The amazing tracks featured on this record were recorded in the Bahamas, Jamaica and Trinidad and Tobago.

The Reverb Conspiracy Volume III

The compilation’s curator Casper Dee says: “I like to look at it as a modern Nuggets series…”. Names you’ll find on the tracklisting includes the likes of Goat and Lola Colt.

Move On Up – The Very Best Of Northern Soul

This mega compilation features 75 Northern Soul hits and rarities from the likes of Frank Wilson, Chuck Wood, Bobby Bland and PP Arnold.

All About Elvis – A Tribute To The King

This 3 CD collection features 97 tracks which celebrate those that sounded like Elvis, artists that were influenced by him and associates of the singer too. It was compiled by Rock And Roll expert Dave Penney.

African Airways One – Connection Funk 1973 – 1979)

This was the first release on new label Africa Seven. Africa Seven are “are a collective of crate diggers, afro music-heads, label spotters and vinyl buying obsessives”.

Shapes: Wires

This compilation came out on Tru Thoughts and was compiled by label co-owner Robert Luis. It encompasses the new artists on the roster right now, as well as remixes and classics.

¡CHICAS! Vol 2. Spanish Female Singers 1963-1978

Described as “an irresistible collection of ye-ye, rock & roll, twist, beat, gipsy rock, soul, and cinematics grooves.” Many of the 28 tracks are reissued for the first time, including some very hard to find records.

Sensible Record Labels

This gorgeous vinyl record was released on Record Store Day. It features eleven tracks, many of which are exclusives, handpicked by eleven indie labels such as Bella Union, Memphis Industries and Fortuna Pop.

New Orleans Funk: The Original Sound Of Funk 1960-75

This was originally released back in 1969 but it’s always a fabulous record to put on to brighten up your day.

Sherwood At The Controls

This is a collection of the producer’s early work from 1979 – 1994. Artists making an apperance on the compilation include The Fall, Prince Far I and The Slits.

Magik Sunset Part 1

A sumptuous collection of painstakingly dug and licenced oddities and rarities, put together by the ever excellent Psychemagik.

Late Night Tales – After Dark: Nocturne

This is the latest in the ‘Late Night Tales After Dark’ series and was compiled by DJ Bill Brewster. It features 19 tracks from the likes of Charli XCX, Alex Metric and Plastic Bertrand.

Perfect Motion – Jon Savage’s Secret History Of Second Wave Psychedelia 1988-93

This special album features tracks by Primal Scream, The High, Electronic and 808 State.

Ain’t Gonna Hush – The Queens Of Rhythm And Blues

This is a stellar collection of 76 classic R ‘n’ B tracks, including the likes of Aretha Franklin, LaVern Baker, Betty Everett and Etta James.

Magic Bus

A great 3 CD collection of tracks from the 60s and 70s that sound tracked the journeys along the US hippy trail.

Ginger Johnson – African Party

This record was riginally released in the late 60s and this is the first time the album has been re-issued. Ginger Johnson was a Nigerian percussionist and band leader, who was considered a mentor to Fela Kuti and as a musician played with many artists including Genesis, Hawkwind and Quincy Jones.

Disco Dildar

The album contains ten rare tracks recorded in Pakistan during the 70s and 80s. This record has been lovingly compiled by Andy Votel and Chris Menist.

Tropical Disco Hustle Vol II

Volume 1 of this fabulous compilation was released last year. This was compiled and researched by Deano Sounds, with edits by French DJ-extraordinary Waxist Selecta and legnedary UK disco DJ Al Kent.

Too Slow For Disco 2

The album follows last year’s ‘Too Slow For Disco’. This was compiled by Berlin producer DJ Supermarkt and features 16 tracks from the late 70s / early 80s.

Masterpiece by Annie Nightingale

A brilliant 3 CD collection highlighting the Radio 1 DJ’s favourite musical finds over a 50 year in broadcasting.

Critical Mass – Splinter From the Worldwide New-Wave, Post-Punk and Industrial Underground, 1978-84

This was released on Touch Sensitive Records and compiled by DJ Cherrystones – the former resident DJ of ATP events, sometimes solo artist, and prolific producer and remix artist.

Jackson C. Frank: The Complete Recordings Track Listing

This CD collection includes the classic Jackson C. Frank album from 1965, some unreleased traditional songs from 1961 and the 1968 Peel Sessions.

The Capitol Northern Soul 7s Box

This super box set contains seven 7” singles containing 14 Northern Soul classics.

60 Songs from The Cramps Crazy Collection

The album features 60 songs that were either played during frontman Lux Interior’s Purple Knif radio show or from the personal record collection he owned with wife and fellow Cramps member Poison Ivy.

Feeling Nice: Volume 3

This Tramp Records compilation includes tracks from Clarence Reid, Saint John, Jack & The Mods, Rickey Andrews and many many more.

This Is Trojan

This 3 CD collection features sixty classic tracks and sleeve notes from 6 Music’s very own Don Letts.

Complete Hit Singles A’s & B’s

This is truly special, it contains 32 of legendary singer Little Willie John’s tracks.

Greater Manchester Punk 1977-81

This album features fourteen rare and previously unreleased tracks from some of Manchester’s punk bands of the time.

MORE Lipstick, Powder and Paint: A Decade Of Girls 1953 – 1962

This is a 90-track, 3 CD set, the second in the ‘Lipstick, Powder & Paint’ series. It includes big-name solo artists from Shirley Bassey, Doris Day, Brenda Lee, Jo Stafford, Aretha Franklin and Connie Francis, to Alma Cogan, Helen Shapiro, Jackie De Shannon, Dionne Warwick, and Freda Payne are present, as are stellar groups like The Chordettes, The Andrews Sisters, The Crystals, The Paris Sisters and Martha & The Vandellas.

From Sacred To Secular: A Soul Awakening

This compilation is released on 8 discs – it takes a look back at the history of Soul Records from 1927-1963 – tracing R&B, jazz and blues, gospel.

Norman Jay MBE Presents Skank & Boogie

On this record Norman leads you through skank, boogie, reggae, funk, disco, and beyond. Released on Rob Da Bank’s label Sunday Best records.

Alone & Unreal – The Best Of The Clientele

This features tracks from each of their previous 5 albums and new single “(I Can’t Seem) To Make You Mine”

Senegal 70 – Sonic Gems & Previously Unreleased Recordings from the 70s

This ace collection has been compiled by Analog Africa and Teranga Beat – a Senegalese label. The compilation reflects “the fusions of Funk, Cuban Son, and Mandigue guitar sounds.”

The Very Best Of Ronnie Spector

A first time compilation for the iconic singer combining her work with The Ronettes, Phil Spector, Keith Richards, Joey Ramone and more, all from 1963-2006

Soul Sok Séga: Sega Sounds from Mauritius 1973-1979

Strut Records’ Soul Sok Séga documents the mind-boggling sounds of Mauritius in the ‘70s, where the country’s traditional séga music, the ‘blues of the Indian ocean’, collided with the Western influence of jazz, funk, and soul.
